Legal_Issue: Did the Officer err in failing to consider a substituted evaluation or positive discretion under subsection 76(3)?
Did the Officer breach the duty of fairness by not allowing more evidence on the wife's education?
Governing_Law: Subsection 76(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application in Federal Court
Evidence_Assessment: Submission letter for substituted evaluation not included in package
Insufficient evidence of wife's full-time studies as requested
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to provide required documentation and meet evidentiary requirements
Legal_Rule: Subsection 76(3) allows visa officers discretion for substituted evaluations
Officers must act fairly but are not obligated to request additional evidence unless required by legislation
Procedural_Issue: Failure to include submission letter in application package
No procedural obligation for officer to solicit further evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in failing to consider substituted evaluation
Alleged breach of duty of fairness
Outcome_on_Merits: Officer did not err; application properly dismissed
Review_Standard: Standard of reasonableness applied to administrative decision
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: No breach of duty of fairness; officer not required to solicit additional evidence
Key_Evidence_Considered: October 2008 letter requesting proof of full-time studies
Missing submission letter on substituted evaluation
Applicant_Challenge: Challenged refusal based on insufficient points and documentation
Defendant_Response: Officer acted within discretionary authority and followed procedural fairness
Governing_Rule: Subsection 76(3) allows discretion for substituted educational evaluation in spousal sponsorship
